projectDesc.p: WorldViews is a multilingual‚ digital resource for primary sources containing excerpts from textbooks from around the world on topics that are of global‚ transnational and interregional relevance. The selected source material from textbooks reveals how the individual countries position themselves in the world and how they portray other countries and their histories. Academic contributions provide more in-depth interpretations of the source material as well as information on the national education and textbook systems and background information on the history of education.

samplingDecl.p: Text excerpts are chosen because they are striking in terms of representation interpretive framework and/or perspective. They are portrayals that are published in widely distributed textbooks or stand out due to their unique standpoint. They are collected by project partners or the editorial team‚ given academic context and translated into German and English paying particular attention to the cultural and historical context of the source text.

abstract.p: The same team of authors already published a History of Cameroon in 1986 which was released in English in 1988. This edition seems to be based on the English version because Christiane Perrin is listed as translator.
The book is designed for students in year 3 and 4 of primary school. It covers the period of the early history up to the independence of Cameroon.

The excerpt deals with the arrival of the first Europeans in Cameroon. The Portuguese arrived in the 15th century and explored the coast. With the help of the Cameroonian coastal population as intermediaries, they traded with people from the interior of the country.

div.p: C'est au 15esiècle que les Européens arrivèrent pour la première fois au Cameroun. Les Portugais furent les premiers Européens à arriver.

En 1469, le roi du Portugal envoya ses marins sur la côte d'Afrique occidentale pour faire du commerce. En 1471, les Portugais découvrirent São Tomé et Principe. En 1472, Fernando Poo, capitaine portugais, aperçut une grande île. II l'appela Formosa. Plus tard, on l'appela Fernando Poo comme lui. Aujourd'hui elle s'appelle Malabo et elle fait partie de la Guinée Équatoriale.
De Fernando Poo, les Portugais aperçurent le Mont Cameroun sur le continent. Ils remontèrent l'estuaire du Wouri. Ils l'appelèrent « Rio-dos-Camaroes » (rivière des crevettes).
[Black and white print of a maritime scene. At the front, there is a Portuguese two-master with billowed sails. In the background, there are several smaller ships. The sky is cloudy.]
Voilà comment le Cameroun eut un nom. Les Portugais l'appelèrent Camaroes, les Franҫais le Cameroun (Kamerun en allemand).
Au cours du 15esiècle, les Portugais explorèrent la côte. Les Portugais commencèrent aussi à faire du commerce.

On établit des comptoirs à Kribi, Victoria, Bimbia, Douala et Rio-del-Rey. Les populations de la côte servaient d'intermédiaire pour le commerce entre les Européens et les peuples de l'intérieur. A cette époque, les Européens n'explorèrent pas l'intérieur du pays.
